Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
In principle, at least, the dropped bullet and the horizontally-fired bullet will hit the ground simultaneously. The physics here is that the fired bullet is coasting horizontally at great speed, but its vertical motion is simply that of a falling object. Both bullets begin to fall at the same time and with the same initial 'vertical component of velocity' -- the projection or portion of velocity that lies along the vertical axis. Both bullets accelerate downward at approximately 9.8 m/s2 and hit the ground simultaneously. We demonstrations like this frequently, but with balls instead of bullets. There are demonstration tools that drop two balls at once; one ball simply falls, while the other ball is shot horizontally by a spring. The two balls really do hit at the same time. The bullet-version would be dramatic and fun, but it would require a huge open space and complicated equipment to show both bullets hitting -- after all, they hit the ground at very different locations. [One final note: this story neglects air resistance, which will cause small discrepancies in the fall times, and it also neglects the curvature of the Earth. If the bullet is fired at too great a speed, it will go into orbit!] Lou

Input.posts:
Hi, In week 4, Dr.Bloomfield talks about the need of thumb rules for specifying directions of rotation. For eg: The right hand thumb rule (see \xA0episode 4 part 1). I understand that and agree with it. But why not just use positive and negative angles (based on which side rotation occurs) and specify the axis like x-axis, y-axis or z-axis. I have used this sometimes in mathematics courses and I wonder why can't we just use these notations to specify direction of rotation?\xA0
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Interesting question! Suppose you are talking on the telephone with a person (Bob) in another galaxy. You and Bob have never met and Bob has never seen anything from our world. Now imagine trying to explain to Bob how to draw our standard 3-axis coordinate system (xyz). You first ask Bob to draw the x-axis and y at right angles to one another. Now you ask Bob to add a z-axis at right angles to both of the x-axis and the y-axis. Bob immediately discovers that there is an ambiguity: in which of two possible directions should the z-axis point? You are looking at your mathematics book, which has a properly drawn xyz coordinate system and try to explain to Bob the direction of the z-axis. But you fail. There is absolutely no way for you to identify it over the telephone. You are truly stuck. The two possible xyz coordinate systems that Bob is trying to decide between are mirror images of one another. That mirror symmetry can't be broken over the phone; it can only be broken by making an arbitrary choice and then showing Bob your choice. You must show Bob an artefact that has a unique 'handedness'. Once you do that, you and Bob have a starting point on which to break the mirror symmetry of any other object, including the xyz coordinate system. For example, if you give the person a right shoe (as opposed to a left shoe), now you can use that artefact to specify what you consider to be the correct xyz arrangement. Any chiral object will do: a book, clock, or a right hand. Without that artefact to establish between two possible mirror symmetry. It turns out that particle physics breaks mirror symmetry in rare cases. It is therefore possible to tell Bob to do some elaborate physics measurements and thereby obtain a local reference with which to determine which xyz coordinate system is our standard. But the basic idea still holds: we use a right hand rule to define our xyz coordinate system and our directions of rotation because a right hand is a familiar and useful artefact. Lou

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
The pound-force (lbf) is an English/American unit of force (not part of the SI or metric system). The force involved doesn't have to be related to gravity; for example, you can push on a floor, wall, or ceiling with a force of 10 lbf (10 pounds-force). When we say that a package of cookie has a weight of 1 pound, we mean that Earth's gravity exerts a downward force of 1 pound-force on it. There is also the pound-mass (lbm), which is an English/American unit of mass. 1 lbm has a weight of 1lbf, for some standard strength of Earth's gravity [I'm not expert in the definitions of these units]. So a package of cookies with a mass of 1lbm weighs 1lbf here on Earth. Suppose you go to the moon, where gravity is only about 1/6th as strong as on Earth. The two units, lbm and lbf, haven't changed. The lbm still defines the same mass, and the lbf still defines the same force. Since mass doesn't depend on gravity, the package of cookies still has a mass of 1 lbm. However, the package of cookies will no longer weigh 1 lbf. It will only weight about 1/6 lbf (0.16 lbf). The cookies will have lost weight (for real; they really do weigh less). But, of course, the cookies themselves haven't changed. Lou

Even if you push hard on that massive ball, it will barely accelerate. On the other hand, a golf ball has a tiny mass and is easy to accelerate. Lou
